Description: Body sherd of Chian Grand Style pottery light chalice; white slip; interior: glazed black; part of lotus flower in added red and added white outline; below, white and red billet pattern between white bands; below, red band; exterior: painted decoration consisting of part of archer, possibly Herakles, with light brown for flesh and black garment(?) with white dots, to right, holding out his bow; at his side, the head of roaring lion, possibly part of a skin, in brown outline to right.
Curator's comments: Lemos describes this sherd as belonging to the Naukratis Painter. The painter and the group are named after a chalice found at Naukratis and the slip on all vessels from this group is a light beige to almost creamy white. Rim patterns are very simple and there is no filling ornament. The depiction of figures, however, is very elaborate. Clothing is rendered highly decorated and naked skin is expertly portrayed.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 111, p. 276, no. 741, pl. III, pl. 97)
Walter-Karydi 1973 / Samische Gefässe des 6. Jahrhunderts vor Christi: Landschaftsstile ostgriechischer Gefässe (p. 140, no. 808)
Price 1924 / Pottery of Naukratis (pl. V, no. 19)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0791) (phase 2)
